Fig. 1 XRD patterns of Fe2O3 and Ag catalysts with different Fe/Ag ratios (a) Fe2O3 [53], (b) Fe/Ag-27, (c) Fe/Ag-19, (d) Fe/Ag-15, (e) Fe/Ag-12. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (A) of (a) Fe2O3 [53], (b) Fe/Ag-27, (c) Fe/Ag-19, (d) Fe/Ag-15, (e) Fe/Ag-12 and pore size distributions (B) of (a) Fe2O3 [53], (b) Fe/Ag-27, (c) Fe/Ag-19, (d) Fe/Ag-15, (e) Fe/Ag-12. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM images and particle size distribution of Ag catalysts with different Fe/Ag ratios (a) Fe/Ag-27, (b) Fe/Ag-19, (c) Fe/Ag-15, (d) Fe/Ag-12. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 H2-TPR results of (a) Fe2O3 [53], (b) Fe/Ag-27, (c) Fe/Ag-17, (d) Fe/Ag-15, (e) Fe/Ag-12. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS spectra of Ag-3d (A),Fe-2p(B) and O-1s (C) of catalysts with different Fe/Ag ratios, (a) Fe/Ag-27, (b) Fe/Ag-19, (c) Fe/Ag-15, (d) Fe/Ag-12. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 CO conversion curves for CO oxidation over (a) Fe2O3 [53] and Ag catalysts with different Fe/Ag ratios (b) Fe/Ag-27, (c) Fe/Ag-19, (d) Fe/Ag-15, (e) Fe/Ag-12. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 CO conversion over Fe/Ag-15 catalyst with different pretreatment atmosphere (a) Muffle furnace, (b) O2, (c) H2, (d) Ar, (e) O2-H2. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 XRD patterns of Fe/Ag-15 catalysts with different pretreatment atmosphere (a) Muffle furnace, (b) O2, (c) H2, (d) Ar, (e) O2-H2. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 H2-TPR results of Fe/Ag-15 catalysts with different pretreatment atmosphere (a) Muffle furnace, (b) O2, (c) H2, (d) Ar, (e)O2-H2. Graphical abstract In this paper, highly active Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts derived from MIL-100(Fe) were synthesized by a traditional wet impregnation method. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), H2-temperature program reduction (H2-TPR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The effects of Fe/Ag ratios and pretreatment atmosphere on the structure and catalytic activity for CO oxidation of Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts were investigated. It was found that rarefied oxygen environment in a muffle furnace was beneficial to the formation of small size Ag0 species and larger specific surface area, which could be due to the reductive gases (H2) produced by the decomposition of MIL-100(Fe) and nitrate. The Ag/Fe2O3 catalyst with Fe/Ag atomic ratio of 15 calcined in a muffle furnace showed a high catalytic performance (T100 = 160 °C), stability and reproducibility, which could be related to the large number of Ag0 species on the surface and larger specific surface area. In addition, the effect of water vapor on catalytic activity was also studied. The activity of Ag/Fe2O3 catalyst with Fe/Ag ratio of 15 was slightly affected by the 1 vol.% moisture in the feed gas, but still show high catalytic activity with T100 = 190 °C. Keywords CO oxidation MIL-100(Fe) Ag/Fe2O3 Porosity 1 Introduction Carbon monoxide is a common toxic gaseous pollutant in daily life, its removal is of great significance to environmental pollution control and human health. Thus, converting it into CO2 is one of the effective controlling methods. Catalytic oxidation process has attracted much attention as an effective route with low energy consumption to remove contaminants, it has been applied to many environmental fields [1–15]. On the other hand, CO molecule is often used as a probe molecule to explore the relationship between catalyst structure and performance. CO catalytic oxidation has received tremendous attention in the past few decades due to its potential application for construction industry, automobiles exhaust treatment, CO detectors and fuel cells [16,17]. The core strategy of catalytic oxidation is to prepare highly efficient catalysts, which remains a high demand for exploring. Recently, much effort has been paid to develop efficient and stable catalysts with cheap transition metal oxides for CO catalytic oxidation at low temperature such as copper oxides [18–22], cobalt oxides [23,24], manganese oxides [25,27], cerium oxides [28] and iron oxides [29–32]. Hereinto, hematite (α-Fe2O3) is widely used as catalysts [33,34], supports [35–37] or sensors [38–40] because of the low cost, high resistance to corrosion, and environmentally friendly properties. In addition, large amounts of oxygen can be present on Fe2O3, which most likely represents the oxygen supply during the oxidation reaction. In the past few decades, Fe2O3 nanocatalysts with various structures have been synthesized for CO oxidation by many researchers [41–43]. Recently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are considered as a potential precursor for nanoporous metal oxides with high surface areas due to its excellent characteristics, such as high surface area, tuneable porosity, well-defined structure and good catalytic selectivity [44–52]. In our previous study, α-Fe2O3 catalysts derived from MIL-100(Fe) achieved a complete conversion for CO to CO2 at 255 °C [53], and its activity can be further improved. Furthermore, a lot of modifications have been performed enhancing the catalytic activity of catalysts by introducing metal oxides such as CuO [54], CeO2 [55]. It also has been found that the catalytic activity of CO oxidation can be significantly increased by introducing a certain amount of noble metal into the iron oxide system such as Au, Pt, and Pd [59–65]. Ag is relatively inexpensive compared with Pt and Au, and exhibits special adsorption abilities of oxygen [55–58]. Low temperature CO oxidation catalysed by inert carriers supported silver catalysts have been extensively investigated [66–68]. However, there are few studies have focused on transition metal oxides supported silver as catalysts for CO catalysis. Narasimharao et al. reported Ag-Fe2O3 nanocomposites for CO oxidation, the mesoporous Fe2O3 was prepared by template synthesis method with pluronic polymer (P123) [69], the reported Ag/Fe2O3 catalyst can completely transformed CO to CO2 at 200 °C, which can be further improved. To the best of our knowledge, very little attention has been paid to discuss the effect of Fe2O3 support derived from MIL-100(Fe) on the structure and catalytic activity of Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts for CO oxidation. In this paper, a series of Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts are prepared by a traditional wet impregnation method. The physicochemical properties and their interaction of Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts for CO oxidation activity will be discussed in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation MIL-100 (Fe) was prepared by a traditional hydrothermal method as previously reported [53]. According to a given amount of iron powder (0.654 g), 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (1,3,5-BDC, 1.76 g), hydrofluoric acid (1.02 mL), nitric acid (0.48 mL) and pure water (56.9 mL), the above reagents were added to the polypropylene bottle with component molar ratio of n (Fe): n (1,3,5-BDC): n (HF): n (HNO3): n (H2O) = 1: 0.67: 2: 0.6: 277. After continuous stirring for five minutes, the mixture was subjected to a hydrothermal treatment at 150 °C for 12 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the resulting solid was collected by filtration, washed with deionized water and dried under 80 °C for 12 h to get light orange bulk crystals. The dried samples were further purified with ethanol under continuous stirring at 70 °C for 4 h, then washed with deionized water and dried under 80 °C for 12 h to obtain high purity MIL-100 (Fe). Silver supported on MIL-100(Fe) with different Fe/Ag atomic ratios were prepared by a traditional wet impregnation method [70]. Support was immersed with a given amount of AgNO3 precursor solution (Fe/Ag atomic ratios of 27, 19, 15, 12 were added) under constantly stirring. The as prepared AgNO3/MIL-100(Fe) samples were aged at room temperature overnight and then dried at 70 °C for 12 h, afterwards those AgNO3/MIL-100(Fe) catalysts were calcined at 430 °C for 2 h in muffle furnace, and the final products were named as Fe/Ag-27, Fe/Ag-19, Fe/Ag-15 and Fe/Ag-12, respectively. 2.2 Catalysts characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) experiments were performed by a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with a Copper Kα radiation monochromatic detector, which with accelerating voltage of 40 kV and emission current 40 mA, and the sample was scanned in the range between 10° and 80° with a scan rate of 5° min−1. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were gotten on a Quantachrome autosorb-iQ-2MP. The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the pore size distribution curves were determined from the adsorption branches calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained by using a JEM 2100 instrument with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. H2-Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were performed with a ChemBET TPR/TPD under 10 vol.% H2 flow diluted with Ar gas. The samples (50 mg) were reduced in a flow of H2/Ar mixture. The temperature was increased from room temperature to 850 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were recorded by ThermoFisher with Al Kαsource, and the binding energies were calibrated internally by the carbon deposit C 1 s binding energy (BE) at 284.6 eV. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was used to determine the content of Ag and Fe in the synthesized samples, which was performed on Optima 8000PE. Temperature programmed decomposition in different atmosphere stream (30 mL min−1) was measured on the flowing reaction system, a mass spectrometer (SHP8400PMS) was used as the detector by heating 5 °C min−1 to 430 °C and maintaining that temperature for 2 h. All prepared samples are put into sealed sample tubes and then stored in a drying vessel to avoid ambient air and moisture. The samples were purged in an Ar atmosphere at 100 °C for 30 min before characterization tests. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements CO catalytic activity measurements were carried out in a fixed-bed flow reactor (6 mm outer diameter) at the atmospheric pressure and with 0.1 g catalysts (20–40 mesh). The reactants were fed with a volume ratio of He/CO/O2 = 79/1/20 at GHSV of 18,000 mL g−1 h−1, a total flow rate is 30 mL min−1 controlled by independent thermal mass flow controllers. The CO concentration was analyzed after 30 min of the reaction by using on-line gas chromatograph (GC 2060) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) equipped with 5A molecular sieve column (length: 3 m, inner diameter: 3 mm). In this paper, the CO conversion(Xco) was calculated from the change of the CO concentration: X c o = [ C O ] i n - [ C O ] o u t [ C O ] i n × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts X-ray diffraction analysis was performed to investigate the crystallite phases of the samples. The XRD patterns of as-synthesized Fe2O3 [53] and Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts with different Fe/Ag ratios are shown in Fig. 1 . All samples exhibit two major diffraction peaks at 2θ = 33.1° and 35.6°, which correspond (104) and (110) lattice plane of α-Fe2O3, respectively. All the diffraction lines are well matched with the standard pattern of pure rhombohedral phase α-Fe2O3 (JCPDS Card NO. 330664). Moreover, with the decrease of Fe/Ag ratio, the half-peak width of α-Fe2O3 (104) crystal planes diffraction peak become firstly wider, indicating the crystallite size of Fe2O3 become smaller. Further increase in the Ag content (Fe/Ag-12), the half peak width become narrower. It can be concluded that a certain amount of silver is beneficial to the formation of small Fe2O3 crystalline grain. In addition, the XRD patterns of a series of Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts show peaks at 38.2°, 44.2°, 64.4°, 77.1°, corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) lattice planes of the cubic structure of Ag, respectively [68], indicating that metal silver particles formed over the supports. As it can be seen, the half-peak width of Ag (111) plane diffraction peak becomes narrower with increasing in silver content, which results in an increase in Ag crystallite size. The crystal sizes calculated with Ag (111) plane by the Scherrer formula further confirmed the size change of silver crystal particles (Table 1 ). At the meanwhile, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 55.2° and 2θ = 65.6° gradually appeared clearly with the addition of Ag, which correspond to the (220) and (311) crystal planes of Ag2O, and other characteristic peaks such as (111), (200), (311) lattice planes are quite ultrafine duo to its overlaps at 2θ = 32.9°, 2θ = 38.1°. Fig. 2 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 2(A)) and pore size distribution curves (Fig. 2(B)) of all prepared catalysts. All the samples show the type-IV isotherms according to IUPAC classification. There are obvious hysteresis loops at a high relative pressure in the range of 0.8-1.0, which can be classified as H3-type hysteresis. With the increase of silver content, the area of the unclosed region becomes larger, indicating that bigger pores formed in the structures; this corresponds to the pore size distribution of 1.5–4 nm and 12–25 nm in Fig. 2(B). The pore size distribution curves were obtained from the desorption branch of the isotherms by BJH (Barret-Joyner-Halenda) method. The pore size distribution of Fe2O3 [53] is mainly in the range of 1.5–4 nm. After compounding with silver, the pore size distribution of Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts is mainly in the range of 1.5–4 nm and 12–25 nm. The pore size distribution range of 1.5–4 nm becomes narrower with the increase of Ag which can be related to the strong dispersion of Ag nanoparticle inside the catalyst pores. At the meanwhile, the specific surface areas and pore volumes of the catalysts also improved with the increase of Ag content (Table 1), which is different form the results previously reported in the literatures [69,71]. These phenomena can be related to the production gas phase by the decomposition of silver nitrate in the channel of MIL-100(Fe), thus promoting the formation of more pores and resulting larger specific surface areas. To investigate the morphological features and silver particle distribution of synthesized Ag/Fe2O3 nanocomposites, TEM micrographs were performed. As shown in Fig. 3 , a plenty of Ag particles can be observed on the surface of Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts. Further increase the Ag content (Fe/Ag-12), many bulky silver particles aggregated on the surface, showing a lower dispersion caused by high Ag content. The mean sizes of Ag nanoparticles follow the order of Fe/Ag-27 (3.8 ± 1 nm) < Fe/Ag-19 (4.4 ± 0.6 nm) < Fe/Ag-15 (4.7 ± 1.2 nm) < Fe/Ag-12 (5.7 ± 1.2 nm). This result is in great agreement with the XRD results. With the purpose of comparing the reduction behavior and Ag-Fe interactions in the nanocomposite samples, H2-TPR analysis was carried out. Fig. 4 presents the H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts with different Fe/Ag ratios. The reduction of ionic Ag is hard to be observed when catalyst employed transition metal oxides as supports, especially we have a low silver content. Two main peaks (420 °C, 600–700 °C) can be observed over Fe2O3 [53]. The sharp peak at lower temperature attributes to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, and the other broad peak at temperature of 600–700 °C is related to transformation of Fe3O4 → FeO → Fe0 [26]. Remarkably, the addition of silver makes the reduction peak of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 shifted to lower temperature. For Fe/Ag-27, the reduction peak of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 shifts to 198 °C, further increasing Ag content, the reduction peak changes as follows: 198 °C → 186 °C → 170 °C → 186 °C. The temperature changes indicate that Fe2O3 can be easier reduced with certain amount of Ag presented in the composite. The interaction of oxygen with the Ag surface helps weaken the Fe-O bonds and thus makes it easy for reduction by hydrogen [27]. Among all the Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts, Fe/Ag-15 obtains the lowest temperature, indicating that Fe/Ag-15 has stronger low-temperature reducibility. XPS analysis provided more information on the electronic state and composition of the catalysts (Fig. 5 ). The high-resolution Ag 3d XPS spectrum shows two individual broad peaks located at 368.1 and 374.4 eV (Fig. 5A), which are assigned to metallic Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2 levels. The broad peaks can be resolved into two peaks upon deconvolution of the spectra. The peak located at 368.2 eV and 367.1 eV were attributed to metallic Ag0 and silver oxide species respectively [72]. However, silver oxides are quite unstable in oxygen atmosphere, the binding energy observed for oxidized Ag species in this work does not quite match with either Ag2O or AgO species. It is clearly seen that upon addition of increasing amount of Ag the peaks sifted to higher energy values indicating increasing contribution of metallic parts. A quantitative analysis of surface Ag0/Ag δ+ molar ratios on the Ag 3d5/2 XPS spectra of Ag-Fe catalysts were summarized in Table 2 , Ag0/Agδ+ molar ratios increase from 1.40 to 3.05 with the increase of silver content. As shown in Fig. 5(B), Fe2p spectrum is comprised of two characteristic binding energy peaks at 710.9 eV for Fe2p3/2 and 724.6 eV for Fe2p1/2. The peak separation between Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 peaks is about 13.7 eV, which is characteristic of oxidation state of Fe3+, indicating the formation of α-Fe2O3 [73]. The broad peaks can also be fitted into several peaks upon deconvolution of the spectra. The two peaks of 709.5 and 710.7 eV, which attribute to Fe (II) and Fe (III) species. Fe2+/Fe3+ molar ratios firstly increase from 0.73 to 1.13 with increasing of Ag content, and then decrease to 0.96 (Table 2), Fe/Ag-15 obtained an optimal proportion. Fig. 5(C) shows the XPS spectrum of O 1s, fitting by two binding energy peaks of about 530.1 eV, 532.1 eV. The peaks at 530.1 eV can be attributed to oxygen species corresponding to Fe2O3, while the other peak at 532.1 eV can be related to oxygen in the electrophilic state adsorbed on Ag [74]. As Table 2 shows, with Fe/Ag ratio decreasing from 27 to 15, the molar ratio of Olatt/Oads increased from 0.31 to 2.78. Fe/Ag ratio further decrease to 12, Olatt/Oads molar ratio decreased to 0.84, Fe/Ag-15 also receive an optimal proportion. The actual Ag weight loading of all Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts (determined by ICP-OES) is listed in Table 1. It is found that actual Ag loadings are 0.87 wt.%, 1.32 wt.%, 3.64 wt.% and 4.34 wt.% for Fe/Ag-27, Fe/Ag-19, Fe/Ag-15, Fe/Ag-12, respectively. One possible reason for the difference between actual value and theoretical value may be attributed to losses of AgNO3 in the preparation process. Furthermore, there must be a significant part of Ag included into the Fe2O3 matrix. This conclusion can be drawn from data in Table 1. Bulk Ag to Fe2O3 ratios (from ICP-OES) seems to be higher than surface Ag to Fe ratios (determined from XPS), which indicates inclusion of Ag particle into the Fe2O3 matrix. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Effect of Ag loadings for CO oxidation Fig. 6 (A) illustrates the catalytic activities of various Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts with different Fe/Ag ratios toward CO oxidation. The same pretreatment process with calcination in a muffle furnace at 430 °C was done before the activity tests. It was found that all silver catalysts can completely oxidized CO to CO2 at a certain temperature, and the activities of the Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts are much higher than that of pure Fe2O3 (T100 = 255 °C [53]). As shown in Fig. 6, with the decrease of Fe/Ag ratio, the CO conversion significantly firstly increases, and then decreases. Fe/Ag-15 catalyst obtains a best activity of T100 = 160 °C. In order to get more detailed comparison about the activity of CO oxidation for different silver catalysts, several catalysts have been listed in Table 3 . The Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts prepared in this work show higher activity for complete conversion than those reported Ag/Fe2O3 [69,71,77–81]. The parameters of reaction rate for CO oxidation was calculated at a specified temperature of 50 °C with the CO conversion lower than 15%. A relational expression of r = (Xco × C0)/mcat was used for calculation, where r is reaction rate (mol g−1 s−1), Xco is the CO conversion at 50 °C, C0 (mol/s) is the initial CO concentration per second, and mcat. is the amount of catalyst. the reaction rate was calculated as shown in Table 3. The influences of internal and external mass and heat transfer were all excluded. The reaction gas composition and total flow rate were the same as the aforesaid CO oxidation reaction. It can be observed that the value of reaction rate is influenced by Fe/Ag ratio. The CO reaction rate over Fe/Ag-15 is 2.07 × 10−7 mol g−1 s−1, which is much higher than that towards the Fe2O3(8.79 × 10−8 mol g−1 s−1), Fe/Ag-27(7.07 × 10−8 mol g−1 s−1), Fe/Ag-19(1.50 × 10−7 mol g−1 s−1) and Fe/Ag-12(1.04 × 10−7 mol g−1 s−1) samples. Based on the above results, it is reasonable to propose that the Fe/Ag ratio of 15 is beneficial for enhancing the activity of Ag/α-Fe2O3 catalyst. The catalytic activity of Fe/Ag-15 showed a good stability for CO oxidation at 132 °C (T50) and 160 °C (T100) and during a continuous reaction time for 24 h (Fig. S1A and B). Moreover, the XRD pattern of the used Fe/Ag-15 is similar to that of the fresh one (Fig. S1C). In addition, the recycling catalytic tests were carried out for three times with Fe/Ag-15 (Fig. S2). Although the activity of 2ed and 3rd decreased slightly, but the catalyst remains high catalytic activity during the tests and the final conversion temperatures rise to 165 °C. It is well known that the changes in silver states strongly influence oxygen adsorption [67], accordingly affecting the catalytic activity. In this research, the surface silver species varied with the amount of silver content. Significantly, the optimal Ag0/Agδ+ molar ratio (Table 2) and better porosity can be obtained over Fe/Ag-15 catalyst, which exhibits the best activity. These results indicate that an optimal ratio of Ag0 to Agδ+ and porosity play important roles for the catalytic activity. Combined with the surface Fe2+/Fe3+ molar ratio results, more abundant oxygen vacancies were formed on the surface of Fe/Ag-15 catalyst due to the relatively higher Fe2+/Fe3+ molar ratio [81]. Therefore, it can be concluded that the existence of oxygen vacancy may accelerate the conversion of CO. 3.2.2 Effect of pretreatment atmosphere for CO oxidation To further discuss the effect of pretreatment atmosphere on the activity of the silver catalysts towards CO oxidation, several pretreatment processes were carried out for comparison. Fe/Ag-15 catalyst with best activity was chosen to display the catalytic performance. Instead of pretreating in muffle furnace, the pretreatment atmosphere involves the following processes, i) O2 pretreatment at 430 °C for 2 h; ii) H2 pretreatment at 430 °C for 2 h; iii) O2 pretreatment at 430 °C for 2 h and additional 1 h H2 pretreatment at 200 °C; iiii) Ar pretreatment at 430 °C for 2 h. It was found that the catalytic activities are highly sensitive to the calcination atmosphere. As shown in Fig. 7 , Fe/Ag-15 pretreated with muffle furnace remains a best activity, while the catalysts pretreated with other several pretreatment atmospheres show complete conversion temperature upper than 250 °C. Fig. 8 exhibits the XRD pattern of Fe/Ag-15 catalyst pretreated with different atmosphere. As it shows, a change in the structure and crystallite size of catalysts occurs under different pretreatment conditions, which could influence the activity for CO oxidation. When the atmosphere is O2, both Fe2O3 and Ag obtain a large crystallite sizes of 37.3 nm and 13.5 nm which calculated with Fe2O3 (104) and Ag (111) lattice plane by Scherrer Equation. Smaller silver and Fe2O3 crystallite sizes can be obtained with H2, Ar and O2-H2 treatment, but they obviously resulted in the changes of Fe2O3 structure, which leads to a lower catalytic activity. Besides, there is no obvious diffraction lines of silver oxide in the XRD over the samples treated in different atmosphere. This result obtained may confirm that ionic Ag species are also important. It can be supposed that too high concentration of metallic Ag does not lead to high activity, there should be an optimal ratio of Ag0 to Agδ+. Fig. S3 shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. S3(A)) and pore size distribution curves (Fig. S3(B)) of catalysts with different pretreatment atmosphere. Physical parameters of the catalysts were summarized in Table S1. The specific surface areas and average pore diameters are much smaller than Fe/Ag-15 pretreated in muffle furnace. This indicates that the calcination in a muffle furnace is more conducive to pore formation, while muffle furnace provides a rarefied oxygen environment duo to its relatively closeness. We can conclude that beside optimal Ag to Agδ+ ratio the high surface area play an important role in catalytic activity. Fig. 9 presents the H2-TPR profiles of the Fe/Ag-15 with different atmosphere. Remarkably, the reduction peak changes as follows: 170 °C (muffle furnace) → 371 °C (O2) → 319 °C (H2) → 282 °C (Ar) → 331 °C (O2-H2). The sample of Ar atmosphere pretreatment is relatively easily to be reduced, but the temperature is still much higher compared with the samples pretreated with muffle furnace. It is worth noting that the muffle furnace only can provide calcination with a rarefied oxygen environment, it is reasonable to result the formation of reductive gases such as H2 [75], which may come from the decomposition of organic ligands of MIL-100(Fe) during thermal treatment procedure. It has been known that the weak reductive atmosphere caused by the release of reductive gas during the calcination is beneficial to the formation of Ag0 species, but it cannot to reduce Fe2O3 completely. To further explore the reductive production during pretreatment, Temperature programmed decomposition (TPD) of as-prepared AgNO3/MIL-100(Fe) sample with Fe/Ag ratio of 15 pretreated with different atmosphere were performed, and the profiles are shown in Fig. 10 . After analyzing by process gas mass spectrometry analyzer, H2 formation peaks were observed. Fig. 10 shows the H2 intensity change of Fe/Ag-15 during calcination with different atmosphere. In the process of Ar pretreatment, hydrogen concentration barely changed. The atmosphere of O2 and the simulated muffle furnace both have sharp peaks, but the difference in activity between the two catalysts is much significant. Therefore, it can be concluded that instantaneous hydrogen production during O2 pretreatment is not quite helpful to catalytic activity. On the contrary, the rarefied oxygen environment of the muffle furnace can produce a small amount of hydrogen, which keeps the hydrogen surrounding the samples. To further verify this conclusion, we reduced O2 flow rate to 10 mL min−1, added H2 with 1.5 mL min−1, Ar 18.5 mL min−1 as the pretreatment atmosphere. The catalytic activity is shown as Fig. S4, the catalytic activity (T100 = 230 °C) is greatly improved compared with O2, However, there is still a difference between the catalyst activity and the pretreatment of the muffle furnace. After all, it is impossible to simulate the real situation of the furnace, but our simulation results have been shown that the pretreatment atmosphere of low oxygen and little hydrogen is conducive to catalytic activity. It was found that the Ag content and pretreatment atmosphere show a great influence on the structure and activity of the catalysts. A possible reaction model of Ag catalyst is proposed and shown in Fig. 11 . When AgNO3/MIL-100(Fe) composites pretreated in a muffle furnace at 430 °C, the carrier MIL-100(Fe) is decomposed into Fe2O3, some large pores are formed and the specific surface area become larger because of the decomposition of nitrate. Meanwhile, the organic ligands of MIL-100(Fe) decomposed producing reductive gases (H2), which promote the formation of Ag0. 3.2.3 Effect of vapor for CO oxidation In order to investigate the water resistance of the catalyst, the activity test of CO oxidation was carried out in the presence of 1.0 vol.% water vapor with Fe/Ag-15 and pure Fe2O3 catalysts. In this study, 1.0 vol.% water vapor was introduced by passing through an Ar flow of 10.7 mL min−1 and a total reaction gas flow of 33.4 mL min−1. The catalytic activity for CO oxidation with 1.0 vol.% water vapor is shown in Fig. 12 . It is observed that the addition of water vapor decreased the CO conversion, the complete conversion temperature for Fe/Ag-15 go up from 160 °C to 190 °C, and the Fe2O3 rise from 255 °C to 300 °C. The lower activity with the presence of water vapor can be due to the preferentially adsorption of water molecule onto active site at the metal oxide surface [76], which effects the oxidation process. 4 Conclusions In this paper, highly active Ag/Fe2O3 nanocomposites were synthesized, the effects of Ag content, pretreatment atmosphere and water vapor on catalytic activity were investigated. In the course of the study, higher surface area over Fe/Ag-15 sample was observed, which may lead to higher accessibility of Ag particles distributed over the surface of the support. The results of activity tests showed that an optimal ratio of Ag0 to Agδ+ also play important role for the catalytic activity. Significantly, the calcination in muffle furnace is beneficial to the formation of Ag0 species and porosity, which could be related to the reductive gases produced by the simultaneous decomposition of nitrate and organic ligands in the rarefied oxygen atmosphere provided by muffle furnace. Moreover, the activity of the catalysts of Fe/Ag-15 and Fe2O3 were affected by the moisture in the feed gas but still show high catalytic activities. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, highly active Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts derived from MIL-100(Fe) were synthesized by a traditional wet impregnation method. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), H2-temperature program reduction (H2-TPR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The effects of Fe/Ag ratios and pretreatment atmosphere on the structure and catalytic activity for CO oxidation of Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts were investigated. It was found that rarefied oxygen environment in a muffle furnace was beneficial to the formation of small size Ag0 species and larger specific surface area, which could be due to the reductive gases (H2) produced by the decomposition of MIL-100(Fe) and nitrate. The Ag/Fe2O3 catalyst with Fe/Ag atomic ratio of 15 calcined in a muffle furnace showed a high catalytic performance (T100 = 160 °C), stability and reproducibility, which could be related to the large number of Ag0 species on the surface and larger specific surface area. In addition, the effect of water vapor on catalytic activity was also studied. The activity of Ag/Fe2O3 catalyst with Fe/Ag ratio of 15 was slightly affected by the 1 vol.% moisture in the feed gas, but still show high catalytic activity with T100 = 190 °C.
coredata.dc:title: High and stable catalytic activity of Ag/Fe2O3 catalysts derived from MOFs for CO oxidation
